statement:
(this proof is not correct yet)

In an ordered geometry a line segment has at most one midpoint.

Let $[p,q]$ be a closed line segment and suppose $m$ and $m'$ are
midpoints. If $m:p:q$ then $[m,p] < [m,q]$ so $m$ is not a midpoint.
Similarly we cannot have $p:q:m$, so we have $p:m:q$. And also,
$p:m':q$. Suppose $m \not = m'$. Without loss of generality we can
assume $p:m:m'$ and $m:m':q$. But then
$[p,m'] > [p,m] \cong [m,q] > [m',q]$ so that
$[p,m'] \not \cong [m',q]$, a contradiction. Hence $m = m'$.
names: a line segment has at most one midpoint
